speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the pain in your wrist and how it started? Was it sudden or did it come on gradually?

speaker: Patient
text: "It started about three months ago, and at first, I thought it was just a minor sprain from the fall I had a few months ago, but it's been getting progressively worse. The pain is usually worse when I'm holding my baby and try to do everyday activities like cooking or typing, and it's really uncomfortable."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the location of the pain in more detail? Is it more on the top of your wrist, the bottom, or is it radiating to your hand or forearm?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's mostly on the top of my wrist, but it's also radiating down to my thumb and elbow, which is what's really concerning me. Sometimes, when I bend my wrist, it feels like a sharp stabbing sensation, but it's hard to describe exactly where it is."

speaker: Doctor
text: So you said it started suddenly, and the pain is more on the bottom of your wrist, radiating towards your forearm. Can you tell me if the pain is constant or does it come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's more of a constant ache, but it's definitely worse at certain times, like when I'm holding my baby or doing activities that strain my wrist. It's not just a sharp pain, but more of a dull ache that's always there, but the sharp stabbing sensation is what really catches me off guard and makes me wince."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the pain when you move your wrist or perform daily activities? Does the pain worsen or improve with certain movements, such as bending, straightening, or twisting?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, when I try to straighten my wrist, the pain seems to be worse. It feels like it's putting extra strain on the area, and I have to be really careful not to move it too much. And when I'm doing activities that involve gripping or holding onto things, like when I'm holding my baby or typing, the pain is really uncomfortable, like it's pressing into my wrist.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me if you've noticed any numbness, tingling, or weakness in your hand or fingers, especially when you move your wrist or perform daily activities?



Also, can you show me the position of your wrist right now, and I'd like you to move it through a range of motion, from fully extended to fully flexed, so I can see how it affects the pain?



REQUEST TEST: Tenderness test on the wrist

speaker: Measurement
text:
RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

No numbness, tingling, or weakness in the hand or fingers, and no other abnormalities observed in the range of motion of the wrist. The wrist appears normal in both fully extended and flexed positions.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you hold out your hand with your palm facing upwards and I'd like you to press the base of your wrist against the exam table, keeping it firmly in place for a few seconds. I'm going to gently press on the top of your wrist now.

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'm holding my hand out with my palm up and pressing the base of my wrist against the table... I'm feeling the pressure, it's a bit uncomfortable, but it's not excruciating. Can you please ease off the pressure a bit now?"

speaker: Doctor
text:
I'd like you to bring your wrist down slowly and then bring it back up to the starting position, and let me know how you feel. Can you tell me if the pain changes at all during this movement?



Also, while you're doing that, I'd like to examine the tendons in your wrist more closely. Can you show me the tendons on the top of your wrist, the ones that run from the forearm to the hand?



REQUEST TEST: Visual inspection of the wrist tendons

It's a bit hard to explain, but it feels like the pressure was putting extra stress on the area, and now that you've released it, I'm feeling a bit of relief, but the pain is still there, just more manageable."

text:

speaker: Patient
text: "I hold my phone mostly with my thumb and index finger, and I try to keep it at a slight angle to avoid putting pressure on my wrist. speaker: Doctor
text:
I'd like to summarize what I've gathered so far. You mentioned that the pain started suddenly and is mainly located on the bottom of your wrist, radiating towards your forearm. You've experienced pain when moving your wrist or performing daily activities, and it's constant. You've noticed a slight pressure when I press on the top of your wrist, but the pain doesn't change significantly with movement. You've also noticed swelling and redness around your wrist, and there's tenderness to the touch.

Can you tell me more about your job or daily activities that involve using your hands? Are you a typist, a mechanic, or someone who performs manual labor?

speaker: Patient
text: "I'm a part-time freelance writer, so I spend a lot of time typing on my laptop and using my phone to check out and make payments. I also do a lot of online shopping, which involves using my phone to navigate and make purchases. I try to take breaks every now and then to stretch my wrist and forearm, but it's hard to avoid putting pressure on my wrist when I'm typing or holding my phone."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your job or daily activities that involve using your hands? Are you a typist, a mechanic, or someone who performs manual labor?

speaker: Patient
text: "I'm a part-time freelance writer, so I spend a lot of time typing on my laptop and using my phone to check out and make payments. I also do a lot of online shopping, which involves using my phone to navigate and make purchases. I try to take breaks every now and then to stretch my wrist and forearm, but it's hard to avoid putting pressure on my wrist when I'm typing or holding my phone. To be honest, I'm not really doing any heavy lifting or manual labor, I'm just using my hands to type and hold things. I guess you could say I'm pretty sedentary when it comes to using my hands."

speaker: Doctor

speaker: Doctor
text:
I've taken note of all the information you've provided. Based on your symptoms and examination findings, I'm going to request one more test to help narrow down the diagnosis.

REQUEST TEST: MRI of the wrist and forearm.

Now that I have all the information I need, I'm going to make a diagnosis.

DIAGNOSIS READY: Tenosynovitis, specifically De Quervain's tenosynovitis, a condition characterized by inflammation of the tendons on the thumb side of the wrist. This condition is common in people who perform repetitive gripping or twisting motions, such as typing or using tools. The tenderness and swelling you've reported, along with the pain and numbness in your wrist and forearm, are consistent with this diagnosis.
